Dive in and see</h1><div class="css-1583yb"><p>AI’s class of corporate investors goes beyond Big Tech.</p></div><div class="css-ecl22i"><div class="css-12ceq0n"><span class="css-10pr93l"><span><a class="css-g65o95" href="/author/jon-keegan/">Jon Keegan</a></span></span></div><div class="css-10k92nq"><div class="css-ed5k1h">11/25/24 9:00AM</div></div></div></div><div data-testid="article-body-content" class="css-d85s7"><p class="css-fiuwhu">Billions of investment dollars are flowing into the coffers of AI startups as the industry scrambles to bet big on which company will dominate the industry in the years to come. </p><div class="css-j0w20r"><div class="css-jo68hd"><iframe title="Billions flowing into AI startups" aria-label="Split Bars" id="datawrapper-chart-ePSW2" src="https://datawrapper.dwcdn.net/ePSW2/1/" scrolling="no" frameborder="0" style="width: 0; min-width: 100% !important; border: none;" height="259" data-external="1"></iframe><script type="text/javascript">!function(){"use strict";window.addEventListener("message",(function(a){if(void 0!==a.data["datawrapper-height"]){var e=document.querySelectorAll("iframe");for(var t in a.data["datawrapper-height"])for(var r=0;r<e.length;r++)if(e[r].contentWindow===a.source){var i=a.data["datawrapper-height"][t]+"px";e[r].style.height=i}}}))}();</script></div></div><p class="css-fiuwhu">Each week brings reports of new fundraising for the private companies leading the pack,  along with eye-popping valuations that <a href="https://sherwood.news/business/elon-musk-xai-valuation-billion-fundraise/" target="_blank" class="css-uubm0" rel="noopener">aren’t exactly</a> justified by the current state of each business. These deals are being <a href="https://www.ftc.gov/news-events/news/press-releases/2024/01/ftc-launches-inquiry-generative-ai-investments-partnerships" target="_blank" class="css-uubm0" rel="noopener">scrutinized by the Federal Trade Commission</a>. </p><p class="css-fiuwhu">To get a sense of which companies from <span class="css-7t8xmc"><a class="inline-stock css-1iix00n" href="https://robinhood.com/stocks/AMZN"><span class="inline-stock-name">Amazon</span></a></span> to  <span class="css-7t8xmc"><a class="inline-stock css-1iix00n" href="https://robinhood.com/us/en/stocks/NVDA/"><span class="inline-stock-name">Nvidia</span></a></span> to <span class="css-7t8xmc"><a class="inline-stock css-1iix00n" from Pitchbook to see who has stakes in OpenAI, Mistral AI, Perplexity, and Anthropic. </p><div class="css-1r17hm4"><div class="css-5veve1"><div data-src="story/2730532?2226965" Edward Moreno</a></span></span><div title="11/29/24 9:53AM" class="css-juyic9">11/29/24</div></div><p class="css-1eyx169">Consumers spent $6.1 billion online on Thanksgiving, up 8.8% from last year, according to Adobe Analytics.</p><p class="css-1eyx169">Holiday shopping was once defined by long lines and chaotic crowds on Black Friday. In the past decade or so, retailers have increasingly spread out their promotions and consumers have come to prefer online shopping. </p><p class="css-1eyx169">The way people are shopping is also changing: Adobe reported a 1,900% increase in traffic to retail sites from chat bots on Thanksgiving. Consumers also spent $430 million online via <a href="https://sherwood.news/business/sezzle-buy-now-pay-later-ceo-charlie-youakim-q-and-a/" target="_blank" class="css-uubm0" rel="noopener">Buy Now Pay Later programs</a>, up 10.3% year of year. </p><p class="css-1eyx169">According to Adobe, some of the most purchased items were toys and gaming consoles.  It projects that shoppers will spend $10.8 billion online for Black Friday, up 9.9% from 2023. </p></div></div></div></div><div class="css-2wm6xu"><a class="css-naqlws" readabilityObject.title: A tangled web of companies have a stake in the biggest AI companies. Dive in and see
readabilityObject.content:
Sherwood News

AI’s class of corporate investors goes beyond Big Tech.

Billions of investment dollars are flowing into the coffers of AI startups as the industry scrambles to bet big on which company will dominate the industry in the years to come.

Each week brings reports of new fundraising for the private companies leading the pack, along with eye-popping valuations that aren’t exactly justified by the current state of each business. These deals are being scrutinized by the Federal Trade Commission. 

To get a sense of which companies from Amazon to Microsoft to Nvidia to Salesforce got in on the ground floor of some of the most promising AI startups, we dove into fundraising data from Pitchbook to see who has stakes in OpenAI, Mistral AI, Perplexity, and Anthropic. 

Consumers spent $6.1 billion online on Thanksgiving, up 8.8% from last year, according to Adobe Analytics.

Holiday shopping was once defined by long lines and chaotic crowds on Black Friday. In the past decade or so, retailers have increasingly spread out their promotions and consumers have come to prefer online shopping.

The way people are shopping is also changing: Adobe reported a 1,900% increase in traffic to retail sites from chat bots on Thanksgiving. Consumers also spent $430 million online via Buy Now Pay Later programs, up 10.3% year of year.

According to Adobe, some of the most purchased items were toys and gaming consoles. It projects that shoppers will spend $10.8 billion online for Black Friday, up 9.9% from 2023.

“Snacks Mix”: Black Friday Special!

Nia Warfield and Jack Raines are joined by Jordyn Holman of the New York Times for a special Black Friday Edition.

  • It's been a big earnings week, which big retailers are positioned to end the year strong?

  • The Black Friday, which sectors will perform well? Are electronics still the name of the game?

  • By the way, where did the term “Black Friday” come from anyway?

OpenAI is bringing in 40 times the annual revenue of Elon Musk’s newcomer xAI, which is trying to compete with the ChatGPT maker. xAI has told investors it’s on track to surpass $100 million annually (most of which is coming from Musk’s other companies), while OpenAI is bringing in $4 billion this year (which notably is not enough to cover its substantial costs). The Wall Street Journal reports how Musk is hoping data from X and Tesla, a stand-alone consumer app like ChatGPT, and breakneck construction speeds will help close the divide.
